column1: The Arc de Triomf (Catalan pronunciation: [ˈaɾk də tɾiˈomf]) or Arco de Triunfo in Spanish
column2: is a triumphal arch in the city of Barcelona in Catalonia
column3: Spain. It was built by architect Josep Vilaseca i Casanovas as the main access gate for the 1888 Barcelona World Fair. The arch crosses over the wide central promenade of the Passeig de Lluís Companys
column4: leading to the Ciutadella Park that now occupies the site of the world fair. It is located at the northern end of the promenade
column5: facing the Passeig de Sant Joan.

column1: The arch is built in reddish brickwork in the Neo-Mudéjar style. The front frieze contains the stone sculpture Barcelona rep les nacions (Catalan for "Barcelona welcomes the nations") by Josep Reynés. The opposite frieze contains a stone carving entitled Recompensa ("Recompense")
column2: a work from Josep Llimona's earliest period
column3: representing the granting of awards to the participants in the World Exposition. The friezes along the sides of the arch include allegories of agriculture and industry by Antoni Vilanova and of trade and art by Torquat Tassó. The two pillars of the arch feature bats carved in stone
column4: which were the emblem of King Jaume I
column5: who ruled over a period of prosperity in Barcelona.

column1: Similar structures can be found in many other cities
column2: most notably including the  Arc de Triomphe in Paris
column4: the Soldiers' and Sailors' Arch in New York City
column5: and the Arcul de Triumf in Bucharest
column6: plus many from the Roman era. This arch
column8: is non-military. It does not celebrate the country's military victories
column9: but rather was built as the gateway to the 1888 World Fair and was thus intended to welcome people.
